tit.j: 多坐弥志理都比古神社

sen.j: 多坐弥志理都比古神社（おおにますみしりつひこじんじゃ）は、奈良県磯城郡田原本町にある神社である。
sen.e: Onimasumishiritsuhiko-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Tawaramoto-cho, Shiki County, Nara Prefecture
Onimasumishiritsuhiko-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Tawaramoto-cho, Shiki County, Nara Prefecture
Onimasumishiritsuhiko-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Tawaramoto-cho, Shiki County, Nara Prefecture

sen.j: 式内社で、旧社格は県社。
sen.e: The shrine is a Shikinai-sha (a shrine listed in Engishiki ["Engishiki" is an ancient book for lows and regulation compiled during the Engi Period, in which shrine listing procedures are included]), designated as a prefectural shrine in the old shrine ranking.

The shrine is a shikinaisha (a shrine listed in the Engishiki [an ancient book of laws and regulations compiled during the Engi era listing shrines]), and was designated a prefectural shrine under the old shrine ranking system.

The shrine is a shikinaisha (a shrine listed in the Engishiki [an ancient book of laws and regulations compiled during the Engi era listing shrines]), and was designated a prefectural shrine under the old shrine ranking system.

sen.j: 一般には多神社（おおじんじゃ）と呼ばれ、多社、多坐神社、太社、意富社とも書かれる。
sen.e: It is generally referred to as O-jinja Shrine, and is also written as "多社," "多坐神社," "太社" and "意富社" in Chinese characters, besides "多坐弥志理都比古神社."
It is generally referred to as O-jinja Shrine, and is also written '多社,' '多坐神社,' '太社' and '意富社' in addition to '多坐弥志理都比古神社.'
It is generally referred to as O-jinja Shrine, and is also written '多社,' '多坐神社,' '太社' and '意富社' in addition to '多坐弥志理都比古神社.'

sen.j: 以下の4座の神を主祭神とする。
sen.e: The following four deities are the main enshrined deities.
The following four deities are the main enshrined deities.
The following four deities are the main enshrined deities.

sen.j: 当地は多氏の拠点であり、祖神として神八井耳命を祀ったものとみられる。
sen.e: The O clan used this district as its base, enshrining Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto as the Soshin (ancestor honored as god).
The O clan used this district as its base, enshrining Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto as the Soshin (ancestor honored as god).
The O clan used this district as its base, enshrining Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto as the Soshin (ancestor honored as god).

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳には「大和国十市郡 多坐弥志理都比古神社二座」と記されている。
sen.e: In Engishiki Jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan), this shrine is listed under 'Toichi-gun, Yamato Province, Onimasumishiritsuhiko-jinja Shrine Niza (enshrining two deities).'
In the Engishiki Jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan), this shrine is listed under 'Toichi-gun, Yamato Province, Onimasumishiritsuhiko-jinja Shrine Niza (enshrining two deities).'
In the Engishiki Jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan), this shrine is listed under 'Toichi-gun, Yamato Province, Onimasumishiritsuhiko-jinja Shrine Niza (enshrining two deities).'

sen.j: 久安5年（1149年）に当社禰宜多朝臣常麻呂が国司に提出した『多神宮注進状』では以下の2座としている。
sen.e: In "Ojingu Chusinjo" (the crops report of the manor of Ojingu) submitted in 1149 to the provincial governor by O-no-Ason Tsunemaro, a Negi (an assistant to Guji [chief priest]), there is a description that the shrine enshrines the following two deities.
sen.cmt: 一例文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: In "Ojingu Chusinjo" (the crops report of the manor of Ojingu) submitted in 1149 to the provincial governor by O-no-Ason Tsunemaro, a Negi (an assistant to Guji [chief priest]), there is a description that the shrine enshrines the following two deities.

In "Ojingu Chusinjo" (the crops report of the manor of Ojingu) submitted in 1149 to the provincial governor by O-no-Ason Tsunemaro, a Negi (an assistant to Guji [chief priest]), there is a description that the shrine enshrines the following two deities.

sen.j: また、社名より水火知男女神（みひしりひこひめのかみ）が神名帳の2座であるとも書かれている。
sen.e: Additionally, it is described that two deities in the Jimmyocho refers to Mihishirihikohime-no-kami after the shrine's name.
sen.cmt: 一例文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Additionally, it is described that two deities in the Jimmyocho refers to Mihishirihikohime-no-kami after the shrine's name.
Additionally, it is described that two deities in the Jimmyocho refers to Mihishirihikohime-no-kami after the shrine's name.

sen.j: 珍子 賢津日霊神尊（うつのみこ さかつひこのみこと） 皇像瓊玉坐 河内国高安郡 春日戸社坐御子神社と同神
sen.e: Utsunomikosakatsuhiko-no-mikoto (the Imperial image existing in Yasakani-no-Magatama [Magatama jewel, one of "Three Sacred Treasures of Japan"): the same deity as Kasuganokoyashironimasu Miko-jinja Shrine located in Takayasu County, Kawachi Province enshrines

Utsunomikosakatsuhiko-no-mikoto (the Imperial image existing in Yasakani-no-Magatama [Magatama jewel, one of "Three Sacred Treasures of Japan"): the same deity as Kasuganokoyashironimasu Miko-jinja Shrine located in Takayasu County, Kawachi Province enshrines

Utsunomikosakatsuhiko-no-mikoto (the Imperial image existing in Yasakani-no-Magatama [Magatama jewel, one of "Three Sacred Treasures of Japan"): the same deity as Kasuganokoyashironimasu Miko-jinja Shrine located in Takayasu County, Kawachi Province enshrines

sen.j: 天祖 賢津日孁神尊（あまつおや さかつひめのみこと） 神物圓鏡坐 天照大神高座神社と同神
sen.e: Amatsuoya Sakatsuhime-no-Mikoto (a deity existing in Yata-no-Kagami [a mirror, one of "Three Sacred Treasures of Japan"): the same deity as Amaterasuokami Takakura-jinja Shrine enshrines
sen.cmt: 神物圓鏡坐の意味不明
sen.e: Amatsuoya Sakatsuhime-no-Mikoto (a deity existing in Yata-no-Kagami [a mirror, one of "Three Sacred Treasures of Japan"): the same deity as Amaterasuokami Takakura-jinja Shrine enshrines

sen.j: 元文2年（1737年）の『多大明神社記』では現在の四座になっている。
sen.e: In "Record of O-Daimyojin Shrine" compiled in 1737, this shrine is described as enshrining four deities like now.
sen.cmt: 一例文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: In "Record of O-Daimyojin Shrine" compiled in 1737, this shrine is described as enshrining the four currently enshrined deities.
In "Record of O-Daimyojin Shrine" compiled in 1737, this shrine is described as enshrining the four currently enshrined deities.

sen.j: 明治時代の『神社明細帳』では本殿の第一社・第四社は摂社の扱いとなっており、主祭神は神八井耳命・神泥川耳命の二座としている。
sen.e: In "Jinja Meisaicho" (Official records of Shinto shrines) compiled in the Meiji period, however, the shrine regards the first and fourth sanctuaries of Honden (main sanctuary) as auxiliary shrines, with two deities of Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto and Kamununakawamimi-no-mikoto enshrined as main enshrined deities.
sen.cmt: 一例文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: In "Jinja Meisaicho" (official records of Shinto shrines) compiled during the Meiji period, however, the shrine regards the first and fourth sanctuaries of the honden (main sanctuary) as auxiliary shrines, with the two deities Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto and Kamununakawamimi-no-mikoto enshrined as the main enshrined deities.

In "Jinja Meisaicho" (official records of Shinto shrines) compiled during the Meiji period, however, the shrine regards the first and fourth sanctuaries of the honden (main sanctuary) as auxiliary shrines, with the two deities Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto and Kamununakawamimi-no-mikoto enshrined as the main enshrined deities.

sen.j: 社名の通りであれば弥志理都比古（みしりつひこ）を祀る神社ということになるが、
sen.e: The shrine's name itself means "a shrine enshrining Mishiritsuhiko."
The shrine's name itself means "a shrine enshrining Mishiritsuhiko."
The shrine's name itself means "a shrine enshrining Mishiritsuhiko."

sen.j: これは神八井耳命のことである。
sen.e: Mishiritsuhiko is the same as Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto.
Mishiritsuhiko is the same as Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto.
Mishiritsuhiko is the same as Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto.

sen.j: 神武天皇の長子でありながら弟に皇位を譲った。
sen.e: Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto gave up the right of succession to the Imperial Throne and handed over it to his younger brother, despite being the eldest child of the Emperor Jinmu.
sen.cmt: 一例文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto gave up the right of succession to the Imperial Throne and ceded it to his younger brother, despite being the eldest child of the Emperor Jinmu.
Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto gave up the right of succession to the Imperial Throne and ceded it to his younger brother, despite being the eldest child of the Emperor Jinmu.

sen.j: ここから「身を退いた」という意味で「ミシリツヒコ」とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto is also referred to as 'Mishiritsuhiko' on the grounds that such conduct as withdrawing oneself from something is translated as 'Mi o shirizoita' in Japanese.
sen.cmt: 一例文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto is also referred to as 'Mishiritsuhiko' on the grounds that such conduct as withdrawing oneself from something is translated as 'Mi o shirizoita' in Japanese.
Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto is also referred to as 'Mishiritsuhiko' on the grounds that such conduct as withdrawing oneself from something is translated as 'Mi o shirizoita' in Japanese.

sen.j: 古くは春日宮と称し、四方に鳥居があったという。
sen.e: Referred to as Kasuga-no-miya Shrine (春日宮) in olden times, the shrine is believed to have had Torii (shrine gate) on every side.
sen.cmt: 春日宮の読みがわかりません。
sen.e: Referred to as Kasuga-no-miya Shrine (春日宮) in ancient times, the shrine is believed to have had a torii (shrine gate) on every side.
Referred to as Kasuga-no-miya Shrine (春日宮) in ancient times, the shrine is believed to have had a torii (shrine gate) on every side.

sen.j: 太陽信仰の聖地であったのか、方位を配慮した構造になっていた様である。
sen.e: The shrine was apparently designed taking directions into consideration, which implicates that this area was regarded as a sacred ground of the sun worship.
The shrine was apparently designed taking directions into consideration, which implies that this area was regarded as a sacred place of sun worship.
The shrine was apparently designed taking directions into consideration, which implies that this area was regarded as a sacred place of sun worship.

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 紀記神話には、「神八井耳命は皇位を弟に譲り、自らは神祇を祭る」とあり、
sen.e: There is a description in Japanese mythology that Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto handed over the Imperial Throne to his younger brother and devoted himself to enshrining deities of heaven and earth.
There is a description in Japanese mythology that Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto handed over the Imperial Throne to his younger brother and devoted himself to enshrining deities of heaven and earth.
There is a description in Japanese mythology that Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto handed over the Imperial Throne to his younger brother and devoted himself to enshrining deities of heaven and earth.

sen.j: それが当社の始まりであるとしている。
sen.e: The shrine interprets this description as the origin of the shrine.
The shrine interprets this description as the origin of the shrine.
The shrine interprets this description as the origin of the shrine.

sen.j: 綏靖天皇2年、神八井耳命は春日県（後の十市県）に邸宅を造り、そこに神籬磐境を立てて自ら神祇を祀った。
sen.e: Building the residence in 580 B.C. in Kasuga-no-agata 春日県 (later Toichi-no-agata 十市県), Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto erected Himorogi Iwasaka (the place where God descends) to devote himself to enshrining deities.
sen.cmt: 春日県と十市県の読みがわかりません。
sen.e: In 580 BC, Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto constructed a residence in Kasuga-no-agata (later Toichi-no-agata) where he erected a primitive shrine where he enshrined deities.
In 580 BC, Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto constructed a residence in Kasuga-no-agata (later Toichi-no-agata) where he erected a primitive shrine where he enshrined deities.

sen.j: 崇神天皇7年、その神祠を改造し、天津日瓊玉命・天璽鏡劔神を祈賽したと伝える。
sen.e: It is believed that Amatsuhinoninotama-no-miko and Amatsushirushi Kagami Tsurugi-no-kami were ceremonially enshrined in 91 B.C. after the shrine was remodeled.
It is believed that Amatsuhinoninotama-no-miko and Amatsushirushi Kagami Tsurugi-no-kami were ceremonially enshrined in 91 B.C. after the shrine was remodeled.
It is believed that Amatsuhinoninotama-no-miko and Amatsushirushi Kagami Tsurugi-no-kami were ceremonially enshrined in 91 B.C. after the shrine was remodeled.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳では「大和国十市郡 多坐弥志理都比古神社二座」と記され、名神大社に列し、月次祭・相嘗祭・新嘗祭の幣帛に預ると記されている。
sen.e: In Engishiki Jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan), this shrine is listed under 'Toichi County, Yamato Province, Onimasumishiritsuhiko-jinja Shrine Niza,' included in the Myojin-taisha Shrine and qualified to receive the offerings to deities in Tsukinami-sai Festival, Ainame-sai Festival and Niiname-sai Festival.

In the Engishiki Jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan), this shrine is listed under 'Toichi County, Yamato Province, Onimasumishiritsuhiko-jinja Shrine Niza,' included in the Myojin-taisha Shrine and qualified to receive the offerings to deities in Tsukinami-sai Festival, Ainame-sai Festival and Niiname-sai Festival.

In the Engishiki Jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan), this shrine is listed under 'Toichi County, Yamato Province, Onimasumishiritsuhiko-jinja Shrine Niza,' included in the Myojin-taisha Shrine and qualified to receive the offerings to deities in Tsukinami-sai Festival, Ainame-sai Festival and Niiname-sai Festival.

sen.j: 永治元年（1141年）の『多神宮注進状草案』では神階正一位となっている。
sen.e: According to "A draft of O-jingu Shrine Chusinjo" (a draft of the crops report of the manor of O-jingu Shrine) completed in 1141, the shrine is conferred the divine rank of the Senior First Rank.
According to "A draft of O-jingu Shrine Chusinjo" (a draft of the crops report of the manor of O-jingu Shrine) completed in 1141, the shrine is conferred the divine rank of the Senior First Rank.
According to "A draft of O-jingu Shrine Chusinjo" (a draft of the crops report of the manor of O-jingu Shrine) completed in 1141, the shrine is conferred the divine rank of the Senior First Rank.

sen.j: 明治時代に郷社に列格し、大正12年（1923年）県社に昇格した。
sen.e: The shrine was designated as a village shrine in the Meiji period, promoted to a prefectural shrine in 1923.
The shrine was designated a village shrine in the Meiji period, and promoted to a prefectural shrine in 1923.
The shrine was designated a village shrine in the Meiji period, and promoted to a prefectural shrine in 1923.

sen.j: 施設
sen.e: Facilities
Facilities
Facilities

sen.j: 本殿は春日造で4棟ある。
sen.e: Main sanctuary was built by employing the Kasuga-zukuri style (a style of shrine architecture employed in main sanctuaries, that has the same basic form as that at Kasuga Taisha Shrine), consisting of four buildings.

The main sanctuary was built in the Kasuga-zukuri style (a style of shrine architecture employed in main sanctuaries, that has the same basic form as that at Kasuga Taisha Shrine), consisting of four buildings.

The main sanctuary was built in the Kasuga-zukuri style (a style of shrine architecture employed in main sanctuaries, that has the same basic form as that at Kasuga Taisha Shrine), consisting of four buildings.

sen.j: 本殿の後方に「神武塚」と呼ばれる小丘があり、古代の祭祀場もしくは古墳と考えられている。
sen.e: Behind the main sanctuary, there is a small hill called 'Jinmu-zuka' (literally a mound of Jinmu), which is considered to have been a place where religious services were held in olden times or tombs.
Behind the main sanctuary, there is a small hill called 'Jinmu-zuka' (literally a mound of Jinmu), which is thought to have been a place where religious services were held in ancient times or a tomb.
Behind the main sanctuary, there is a small hill called 'Jinmu-zuka' (literally a mound of Jinmu), which is thought to have been a place where religious services were held in ancient times or a tomb.

sen.j: 境内社として熊野神社・住吉神社・春日神社・石上神社・竈神社・八幡神社がある。
sen.e: Nono-jinja Shrine (能野神社), Sumiyoshi-jinja Shrine, Kasuga-jinja Shrine, Ishigami -jinja Shrine, Kamado-jinja Shrine and Hachiman-jinja Shrine are Keidai-sha Shrine (shrines in precincts).
sen.cmt: 能野神社の読みがわかりません。
sen.e: Nono-jinja Shrine, Sumiyoshi-jinja Shrine, Kasuga-jinja Shrine, Ishigami -jinja Shrine, Kamado-jinja Shrine and Hachiman-jinja Shrine are keidaisha (auxiliary shrines within the precinct of the main shrine).

Kumano-jinja Shrine, Sumiyoshi-jinja Shrine, Kasuga-jinja Shrine, Ishigami -jinja Shrine, Kamado-jinja Shrine and Hachiman-jinja Shrine are keidaisha (auxiliary shrines within the precinct of the main shrine).
sen.cmt: 原文誤り: 能野神社→熊野神社Nono-jinja Shrine→Kumano-jinja Shrine

sen.j: 境外摂社として以下の神社があり、どれも式内社である。
sen.e: The following shrines are Keigaisessha (auxiliary shrines standing outside the precincts), all of which are ranked as Shikinai-sha.
The following are keigaisessha (auxiliary shrines outside of the precinct of the main shrine), all of which are shikinaisha.
The following are keigaisessha (auxiliary shrines outside of the precinct of the main shrine), all of which are shikinaisha.

sen.j: 『五郡神社記』では本社二座と下記の四皇子神をもって「意富六所神社」と称している。
sen.e: In the "Go-gun Jinja ki" (a record of shrines in five counties), the shrine is referred to as 'Orokusho-jinja Shrine' that consists of main sanctuary enshrining two deities and following four shrines enshrining the following four members of Miko-no-kami.

In the "Go-gun Jinja ki" (a record of shrines in five counties), the shrine is referred to as 'Orokusho-jinja Shrine' and it is stated that it consists of a main sanctuary enshrining two deities and the following four shrines enshrining the following four members of the Miko-no-kami.

In the "Go-gun Jinja ki" (a record of shrines in five counties), the shrine is referred to as 'Orokusho-jinja Shrine' and it is stated that it consists of a main sanctuary enshrining two deities and the following four shrines enshrining the following four members of the Miko-no-kami.

sen.j: 小杜神社（祭神 太安万侶） 式内小社・小社神命神社
sen.e: Komori-jinja Shrine (enshrined deity: O-no-Yasumaro), Shikinai-shosha (literally, small Shikinai-sha) ・Shosha Shinmei-jinja Shrine
Komori-jinja Shrine (enshrining O-no-Yasumaro): the small shikinaisha referred to by the name Shosha Shinmei-jinja Shrine
Komori-jinja Shrine (enshrining O-no-Yasumaro): the small shikinaisha referred to by the name Shosha Shinmei-jinja Shrine

sen.j: 皇子神命神社（祭神 皇子神命）式内小社・皇子神命神社（論社）
sen.e: Mikonokaminomikoto-jinja Shrine (enshrined deity: Mikonokami-no-mikoto), Shikinai-shosha ・Mikonokaminomikoto-jinja Shrine (ronja [shrines considered to be descendants of a Shikinai-sha])
Mikonokaminomikoto-jinja Shrine (enshrining Mikonokami-no-mikoto): the small shikinaisha referred to by the name Mikonokaminomikoto-jinja Shrine (supposed)

sen.cmt: 論社＝ronja (shrines considered to be descendants of a shikinai-sha)としました。

sen.j: 姫皇子命神社（祭神 姫皇子命）式内小社・姫皇子命神社（論社）
sen.e: Himemikonomikoto-jinja Shrine (enshrined deity: Himemiko-no-mikoto), Shikinai-shosha ・Himemikonomikoto-jinja Shrine (ronja)

sen.j: 屋就神命神社（祭神 屋就神） 式内小社・屋就神命神社
sen.e: Yatsugikaminomikoto-jinja Shrine (enshrined deity: Yatsugi-no-kami), Shikinai-shosha ・Yatsugikaminomikoto-jinja Shrine
Yatsugikaminomikoto-jinja Shrine (enshrining Yatsugi-no-kami): the small shikinaisha referred to by the name Yatsugikaminomikoto-jinja Shrine.
Yatsugikaminomikoto-jinja Shrine (enshrining Yatsugi-no-kami): the small shikinaisha referred to by the name Yatsugikaminomikoto-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 昭和47年、当社裏の飛鳥川築堤工事中、境内より縄文時代から古墳時代の遺跡が発見された。
sen.e: While Asuka-gawa River running behind this shrine was embanked in 1972, remains over a period from the Jomon period to the Kofun period (tumulus period) were discovered.
During work to bank the Asuka-gawa River which runs behind the shrine in 1972, remains spanning a period from the Jomon period to the Kofun period (tumulus period) were discovered.
During work to bank the Asuka-gawa River which runs behind the shrine in 1972, remains spanning a period from the Jomon period to the Kofun period (tumulus period) were discovered in the precincts.
sen.cmt: 境内より、を補足しました。

sen.j: 祭礼
sen.e: Sairei-festival
Festival
Rites and Festivals
sen.cmt: 他のファイルの用語に合わせました。

sen.j: 祭礼は4月第三日曜日で、大連座（大和で祭りのことをレンゾと言う）と呼ばれる。
sen.e: Sairei-festival is held on the third Sunday in April, called Dairenzo (literally, big renzo, a festival is called "renzo" in the ancient or primordial Japanese language).
The festival called Dairenzo (literally, big festival. The ancient primordial Japanese word for festival is 'renzo') is held on the third Sunday in April.
The festival called Dairenzo (literally, big festival. The ancient primordial Japanese word for festival is 'renzo') is held on the third Sunday in April.

sen.j: 旧暦使用の時代では春分の頃、祭礼を行っていたという。
sen.e: When Japan adopted the old lunar calendar, the festival was held on a day around the Vernal Equinox Day.
When Japan adopted the old lunar calendar, the festival was held on a day around the Vernal Equinox Day.
When Japan adopted the old lunar calendar, the festival was held on a day around the Vernal Equinox Day.
